content: Offshoring, also known as offshore outsourcing, involves U.S. businesses contracting with firms outside the country to provide services that would have been done by in-house employees. This practice has expanded from blue-collar to white-collar occupations, raising concerns about job loss among U.S. workers. Offshoring, or offshore outsourcing, has evolved from U.S. manufacturers to service providers, leading to concerns about job loss among U.S. workers. The unemployment rate remains high, raising questions about the labor market implications of offshore outsourcing. Some believe it has contributed to "jobless recoveries" from past recessions. The labor market implications of offshore outsourcing during the 2009 recession were unclear. Some believed it contributed to job loss, while others argued that the historical link between economic growth and job creation would eventually lead to recovery.
